Entries.default: Your vantage among the hooded witnesses affords you a view of both the inquisitors and the accused. You recognize the latter as the spirit shackled near the portal above.

"We gather in the sight of Woedica and Wael to thresh truth from falsehood and see justice upheld."

The voice seems to echo from nowhere in particular, though the figures before you present the tableau of a trial in progress.
You hold the court's attention. Masked inquisitors look upon you, stiff-backed and confident in their authority. Hooded figures line the pit, attentive to the proceedings.
[Use the broken dagger relic to take on the role of the accused.]
[Use the broken dagger relic to take on the role of a witness.]
"How do you answer these charges?"
"I deny them. What evidence do you have?"
"I accept them. I have wronged the gods, and I pray forgiveness."
"I reject your authority! This court is a sham set to fulfill the will of Thaos!"
"She's lying."
[Say nothing.]
[Attack] "Enough of this sham!"
The court's many figures erupt in hissing whispers.
"No person present disputes the facts. Your words and actions are a matter of record, confessed by your allies and confirmed by innumerable eyes."
The court's many figures erupt in hissing whispers.
"If my guilt is presumed, why are we here?"
"A smart system you've got here. Who needs truth when you've got zeal?"
"Am I not allowed to know the specifics of the charges?"
"Then I suppose I'm guilty."
"I apologize for my outburst. Go ahead and present the evidence against me."
[Attack] "I'd rather die than bow to you."
The other witnesses step away from you as the masked inquisitors turn their eyes towards your outburst.
"The accused sought my assistance in thwarting this tribunal."
"She claimed to me to be a disciple of Iovara."
"Sorry, I meant you're lying. This court is nothing but a tool to further the power of Thaos."
"No person present disputes the facts. Your words and actions are a matter of record, confessed by your allies and confirmed by innumerable eyes."
"The intruders turn arms against this body! Destroy them!"
[Attack] "Enough of this."
"That's a fair question."
[Say nothing.]
"Your admission does you credit, even if its tone does not."
A quiet murmur passes through the gathered witnesses, and the inquisitors exchange glances. The foremost figure, though, raises a bony hand, her robe slipping to reveal a dusky arm.
"May the gods have mercy upon your soul."

"Then die you shall." 

She raises her hand, the robe slipping to reveal a dark, bony arm, and weapons appear among the gathered Engwithans.

"The matter before this tribunal tonight - heresy."

The dagger you took from the shackled spirit warms to the touch, oozing oily black ichor.
[Attack the gathered court.]
"You hereby stand accused of rejecting the orthodoxy delivered unto us by the universal divinities."
"In your malice, ignorance, and hubris, you would assault the very foundations of civilization."
"I deny them. I serve the gods with every fiber of my being."
"Oh absolutely guilty. The gods are assholes."
"Such contrition is admirable - and rarely witnessed within this hall."
The court's many figures erupt in hissing whispers.
"You're still upset about the castle, aren't you?"

"Alas, the gods grant us no leave to pardon your sins. Absolution can be found only upon the Wheel."

The gathered inquisitors and witnesses nod.
"Thereby does this body deliver unto you the following sentence - You shall be branded upon the soles of your feet to purify you of your earthly taint."
"Then you shall be marched to the sea and drowned, that Ondra might take your breath and wash the lies spoken with it from memory."
"I accept this penance."
"Are you kidding?"
[Attack] "If I'm to die, it'll be here on my feet!"
"We are not. Nor do we appreciate your tone."
"The sentence has been pronounced, and so shall it be carried out. All praise be to the gods."
"Many have made similar claims within these walls. If only words bore the weight of actions."
"Your pettiness does not vindicate you. In poisoning your lips, you contaminate only yourself."
"Thereby does this body deliver unto you the following sentence - You shall be branded upon the soles of your feet to purify you of your earthly taint."
"Then you shall be marched to the sea and drowned, that Ondra might take your breath and wash the lies spoken with it from memory."
"Fantastic. I needed to have a word with Berath."
"I doubt they shall take mercy upon you."
"This body provides you with a final chance to ameliorate the sins you have heaped upon yourself."
"If you choose not to admit fault - not to display contrition - then you shall bear the full burden of your transgressions with you to the Wheel."
"This tribunal derives its authority from the divine and concerns itself not with your acceptance of it."
"If you choose not to avail yourself of the opportunity for contrition, then we shall proceed to the sentencing."
"Silence!"
"Your eyes shall be plucked from their sockets and turned upon you, that you may fully examine your deficiencies."
"Then you shall be chained within a copper tub and your skin opened at two score and seven points, that your spirit might better fly your corrupt flesh."
"Once purified, your soul shall be bound within an animat, that it may serve the gods forevermore."
"Let's get to purifying me, then. I imagine it'll take a while."
"Damn you, damn your gods, and damn your court!"
"The sentence has been pronounced, and so shall it be carried out. All praise be to the gods."
"You hereby stand accused of rejecting the orthodoxy delivered unto us by the universal divinities."
"In your malice, ignorance, and hubris, you would assault the very foundations of civilization."
"How do you answer these charges?"
"I bear guilt for many things, but in my service to the divine I have never wavered. Never once."
The other witnesses step away from you as the masked inquisitors turn their eyes towards your outburst.
"Does the witness have testimony to present?"
The court's many figures erupt in hissing whispers.
"This tribunal derives its authority from the divine and concerns itself not with your acceptance of it."
"You know as well as I that the gods were forged by the leaders of Engwith from their own souls."
"Sure it does, assuming the divine is an old man in a silly hat."
[Say nothing.]
[Attack] "We will not suffer your lies!"

"You would bring words of heresy into this hallowed hall?"

She looks to the gathered witnesses.
"Put him to death."
The inquisitor returns her attention to the shackled spirit.
"Don't suppose you considered not flapping your ballast hole, Captain Watcher?"
"I- I've done no such thing!"
Xoti's lips part as if she might interrupt, but she instead falls silent. She puffs out her cheeks above crossed arms.
"It seems my guilt a foregone conclusion. Why then bother with this farce?"
"Enough of your lies."
The inquisitor turns her masked visage on you.
"We would thank you to keep your tongue civil or stilled, lest it be removed."
"This body provides you with a final chance to ameliorate the sins you have heaped upon yourself."
"If you choose not to admit fault - not to display contrition - then you shall bear the full burden of your transgressions with you to the Wheel."
"Then declare your sentence. What example will be made of me?"
"Apologies, inquisitor."
[Say nothing.]
[Attack] "Or I could remove your head."
She again addresses the accused.
"Your eyes shall be plucked from their sockets and turned upon you, that you may fully examine your deficiencies."
"Then you shall be chained within a copper tub and your skin opened at two score and seven points, that your spirit might better fly your corrupt flesh."
"Once purified, your soul shall be bound within an animat, that it may serve the gods forevermore."
[Say nothing.]
[Say nothing.]
The spirit's head falls, her hair draping her face.
"All praise the gods!"
"Don't suppose I could get that animat after?"
[Say nothing.]
"Silence!"
"Watcher, it is full of souls that have been tortured for millennia. Let them be."
